text: as part of its campaign to show a more
open side the Chinese government is set
aside three areas in Beijing for public
protests during the Olympics the
government said that so long as people
obtained approval and followed the rules
and demonstrations will be allowed I
decided to test the limits of free
expression in China today I decided to
apply to hold a protest
I went along to the Beijing Public
Security Bureau together with the times
video journalist
after some discussion with some
officials there they let us deep into
the heart of the public security
building we've come to a branch of the
Beijing Public Security Bureau to apply
for a permit to hold the demonstration
here in Beijing they took our IDs they
interviewed us about our purpose and
then they kind of disappeared and left
us in this it is anti run for the next
hour or so the police went over the
protest law in laborious to tail the
application has to list the name list of
everybody who shows up along with their
identity card documents and if there any
Chinese nationals on that list they have
to show up at the Public Security Bureau
in person to be approved the protest
zones have been almost completely empty
during the Olympics I can't find any
evidence that any single protest has
actually been allowed the Beijing Public
Security Bureau had this incredible
infrastructure what it didn't actually
have was a real system to actually
tolerate protests one can argue that
this is a completely meaningless
exercise but I do think that in a
Chinese context it is a measure of
progress the Olympics have become a
window into modern China and the litmus
test of human rights and political
protest and political freedom in China
today the kind of news that gets the
attention from China tends to be the
arrest of dissidents or the crackdowns
on Tibetans and those are real and
should be condemned but there's also a
larger truth that we shouldn't lose
sight of if you compare China today to
China a half dozen years ago the great
majority of people have far more
personal space than they ever did before
ordinary people don't need to get
permission to move to a different city
to find a new job to marry China does
have a lot of freedom to let people live
their lives the way they want you this
isn't that the government has expanded
freedom intentionally it's really more
that people have grabbed that freedom
and society has changed middle class has
grown so that freedom has accrued
without it actually being granted I
think in the West people sometimes have
the impression that china is this
country seething with just end where
dissidents are grabbed and tossed into
jail and it's so much more complex than
that
nor indeed a lot of people who were very
upset about corruption about
mismanagement and yet one reason the
poll looked at people all around the
world i founded those in China we're
actually the most content can't mistake
it for a democracy but you also can't
mistake it what existed five or ten
years ago I think it's important for
Westerners to maintain the criticism and
and push for greater human rights within
China but it's just as important to
acknowledge there really has been
progress and that the China of today is
not the same as the China of the decade
ago
